docs.lead_paragraph: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has come up with a new capitalist wrinkle to woo workers to the union banner: slick television spots. The 13-million-member labor federation will begin broadcasting advertisements today in five cities, showing workers, with hip music in the background, explaining how unions have helped them.

headline.main: Unions Plan To Borrow Business Tool: Ad Campaign

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO will launch $5 million advertising campaign, with slick television spots in five cities aimed at wooing workers to union (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Before the strike against the United Parcel Service began, Christopher Holdip, a muscular 29-year-old Brooklynite, worked three sweaty hours an evening unloading 15 trucks, and earned $120 a week -- not enough, he complains, to allow him to move out of his mother's apartment. Miriam Corbblah, like Mr. Holdip, is a part-timer at U.P.S.'s hulking Manhattan sorting center, at 43d Street along the Hudson River. The $190 a week she earns delivering air packages is not enough to lift her and her three children off welfare.

headline.main: Part-Time Workers at U.P.S. See Cause for Full-Scale Fight

docs.abstract: Officials at United Parcel Service say it would not be practical to meet key demand of striking Teamsters, to convert many part-time jobs to full-time ones, because company's day is made up of busy bursts and long lulls; union says company's real motive is to keep most of workers in lower tier of two-tier wage system, paying part-timers half hourly wage earned by full-timers, most of whom are drivers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton wielded the first-ever line item vetoes yesterday, erasing three individual pieces of legislation that he had signed into law last week. If the Supreme Court does its job, and rejects the new line item veto law as unconstitutional, the first ever will also become the last ever. The problem with yesterday's vetoes is not that the three items were examples of marvelous public policy. The trouble lies with the line item veto itself, which unconstitutionally shifts power over spending and taxation from Congress to the President. The three budget provisions were part of a Congressional give-and-take that the Constitution does not, and should not, allow the President to pick apart piecemeal.
docs.abstract: Editorial suggests Pres Clinton's use of line-item veto to erase three individual pieces of legislation from budget bill is unconstitutional (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On June 2, 1995, Luis Caplan closed the door to his medical office in the South Bronx for the last time. For several years after his cancerous left leg was amputated in 1990, Dr. Caplan kept his general practice going, treating the mostly poor and Spanish-speaking patients he had taken care of for more than two decades.

headline.main: Doctor Finds That Working Too Long Costs Him Social Security Payments
headline.kicker: What Is Disabled? He Thought He Knew

docs.abstract: Dr Luis Caplan kept his general practice going for several years after his cancerous left leg was amputated in 1990; he closed door to his medical office in South Bronx for last time on June 2, 1995; Caplan, who was 58 at time, applied for Social Security disability insurance; he received $1,235 in disability checks every month; Social Security Administration informed him in March that he was not entitled to payments and he had to pay back $24,813.90 in benefits he had received; SSA rules say that if person who has been on disability insurance returns to work, he has total of four years in which to decide if working with disability is too difficult; if he does not stop working by then, Federal Government considers him unhindered by disability and ineligible for benefits; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: On the day that President Clinton signed into law the largest expansion of health insurance for children in 30 years, I was disappointed to see Douglas J. Besharov (Op-Ed, Aug. 5) use my own research to attack that policy.
docs.abstract: Letter from Asst Treas Sec Jonathan Gruber disputes Douglas J Besharov's August 5 Op-Ed article criticizing Clinton Administration's health proposals for uninsured children (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    On the day that President Clinton signed into law the largest expansion of health insurance for children in 30 years, I was disappointed to see Douglas J. Besharov (Op-Ed, Aug. 5) use my own research to attack that policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Late last year, Senator Edward M. Kennedy began his latest crusade for health insurance with a seemingly quixotic idea: providing coverage for millions of uninsured children by raising taxes on one of Washington's most powerful special interests, the tobacco industry. But last week, as President Clinton signed into law a bill to balance the Federal budget by 2002, one of the most widely touted provisions was a plan to provide $24 billion for health coverage for uninsured children, much of the money raised through increased taxes on cigarettes.

headline.main: Through Senate Alchemy, Tobacco Is Turned Into Gold for Children's Health

docs.abstract: Article describes complex political maneuvering, backroom political skills and fortuitous timing that allowed funds earmarked for child health insurance program in budget legislation passed by Congress to grow from $16 billion to $24 billion, even though as recently as month ago it seemed close to dead (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The new management of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the largest for-profit hospital chain in the country, vowed last week to drop business practices that have led to criminal indictments, conflict-of-interest charges and a sullied reputation. But as the company changes its personality, it is important that Columbia/HCA and its critics draw the proper lessons about what did and did not go wrong. Under the strong-willed leadership of Richard Scott, forced out last month by Columbia/HCA's board, the corporation gobbled up, Rambo-like, hundreds of hospitals and clinics across the country. Its aggressive takeover tactics shook up the tranquil world of nonprofit hospitals, which had grown complacent and bloated with a seemingly open spigot of Government and private insurance money. Mr. Scott's tactics scared nonprofit hospitals into cutting waste or risking extinction.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges critics to draw proper conclusions from scandals at Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, that have led to criminal indictments, conflict-of-interest charges and sullied reputation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ferry to Corfu Q. I've heard of a ferry that goes from Venice to Corfu. Can you provide information on this service and on service to other Greek islands? How does one get schedules and fares? -- H. T. Masters, Pittsburgh A. There is, indeed, a ferry between Venice and Corfu, but it takes 25 to 30 1/2 hours, depending on the day of the week. This is hardly surprising since you're traveling almost the entire length of the Adriatic. You might want to consider Brindisi, at Italy's heel, a popular point of departure for travelers headed for Greece from Italy. A port since ancient times, Brindisi is just eight hours from Corfu today and is served by at least half a dozen cruise lines.

headline.kicker: Health Care Law Shows Big Government Lives

docs.abstract: Thomas K Gilhool letter says Congress ought to require employers to provide children's health benefits, to answer concern that Government insurance will encourage elimination of private coverage for low-wage workers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the history is written of America's mid-1990's economic boom, a fat chapter will certainly be devoted to the mystifying strength of corporate profits -- how they were able to rise so fast for so long. But there must also be a chapter that describes what happened when this extraordinary performance became ordinary, or worse. And the material for this second chapter seems to be falling into place now. Part of the foundation undergirding the boom is quietly being eaten away. Stagnant wages -- the workers' contribution to their bosses' profits -- are beginning to rise. And there is agitation for more improvement. Workers for the United Parcel Service began a nationwide strike last week that was partly a protest against the insecurities of the Age of Downsizing. As if on cue, stock prices fell sharply on Thursday and Friday, suggesting the vulnerability of another engine of prosperity to shifting circumstances.

headline.main: What Goes Up Must Usually, Well, Stop Going Up

docs.abstract: Stagnant wages are beginning to rise, eating away at foundation of America's mid-1990's economic boom; more than usual, stock market and economy have fed off strength of profits at expense of wages, which along with benefits declined as percentage of national output to their lowest level in more than decade; some economists and business executives attribute economic boom to increased productivity, but others disagree; photos; graphs (M)
